title.narrative: Leveraging Health Service Equity Approaches for Sustainable HIV Epidemic Control

description.narrative: Quality Improvement: The purpose of this program is to develop and expand unique platforms to bring best practices from domestic experiences to assist the global HIV/AIDS program to sustain the goal of reaching epidemic control in Malawi, Zambia and other PEPFAR-supported countries. Funds will be used to continue and scale current HRSA activities for impact in HIV/AIDS treatment services in Malawi, Zambia and other PEPFAR-supported countries.

title.narrative: CDC: Global Health Programs (Polio Eradication)

description.narrative: CDC has provided epidemiologic, laboratory, programmatic expertise, and funding support to help polio-endemic countries with polio eradication activities. The Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI) goal is to eradicate polio and certify the world as polio-free as soon as possible.

title.narrative: ASPR: Building and Strengthening the International Health Regulations - Pandemic Influenza and Other Emrging Public Health Threats

description.narrative: Collaboration with the Pasteur Institute through participating Pasteur Institute affiliates in selected countries in Africa and Asia to develop and implement activities for preparedness and response for pandemic influenza with applicability to other emerging respiratory infections and public health threats in general. These efforts will concentrate on early detection, characterization and early warning of novel influenza outbreaks to drive emergency response operations and decision making in support of national authorities within host countries, as well as international authorities such as the WHO.

title.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: Cooperative Agreement with Institute Pasteur International Network on International Health Regulations

description.narrative: Collaborate with Institute Pasteur International Network (IPIN) affiliates in Asia, Africa, Latin America to build country and regional International Health Regulations (IHR) capacities for public health emergency preparedness and response with the goal of connecting national bio surveillance and laboratory systems created under previous cooperative agreements to fully functional IHR National Focal Points and emergency operation centers to facilitate rapid reporting of outbreaks and other public health emergencies.

title.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases - International Health Regulations

description.narrative: Addressing emerging infectious diseases and international health regulations. U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases (NCEZID) works with partners around the world to prevent illness, disability, and death caused by a wide range of infectious diseases - from the rare but deadly, like anthrax and Ebola, to the more common, like foodborne disease and healthcare-associated infections.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Global Health

reporting-org.narrative: Department of Health and Human Services

title.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: Global Disease Detection (GDD) Program

description.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Center for Global Health (CGH) Division of Global Health Protection (DGHP) Global Disease Detection (GDD) Program builds global health security capacity to respond to infectious disease threats and protect lives by helping countries meet their commitments to the World Health Organization (WHO) International Health Regulations (2005). The GDD Program engages with ministries of health and other implementing partners to improve the local capacity in technical areas such as epidemiology, emergency management and response, laboratory biosafety and biosecurity, quality management systems, and level-appropriate diagnostic methodologies.

title.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: Global Health Activities

description.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Center for Global Health (CGH) leads the execution of CDC's global health approach, working in partnership to assist Ministries of Health to plan, manage effectively, and evaluate health programs; achieve U.S. Government program and international organization goals to improve health, including disease eradication and elimination targets; expand CDC's global health programs that focus on the leading causes of mortality, morbidity and disability, especially chronic disease and injuries; generate and apply new knowledge to achieve health goals; and strengthen health systems and their impact.

title.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: Global Malaria Program

description.narrative: Through the U.S. President's Malaria Initiative (PMI), U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) provides scientific leadership in the public health efforts to fight malaria, increasing global understanding and capacity to prevent death and illness from malaria, especially among vulnerable populations. CDC science has made critical contributions to our understanding of the impact of drug resistance and ways to prevent its spread. In addition, CDC has long worked closely with National Malaria Control Programs to build their technical leadership and capacity to implement effective prevention and control. Through PMI, CDC continues this work, by sharing its technical expertise, particularly in the following areas: (1) design and implementation of monitoring and evaluation; (2) surveillance of malaria; (3) operational research; (4) case management (including diagnostics); (5) entomology/vector control; (6) laboratory support.

title.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: Immunization and Respiratory Diseases (Pandemic Influenza - International Surveillance)

description.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Influenza Division International Program works with a wide range of international partners, including the World Health Organization, National Ministries of Health and others to build capacity to respond to pandemic influenza and to prevent and control seasonal influenza. Core activities include helping establish, expand, and maintain influenza surveillance and laboratory capacity, helping develop global and local pandemic plans and influenza prevention policies, supporting targeted research projects to address critical needs, and building the evidence base for decisions on influenza vaccine program expansion.

title.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: International Emergency and Refugee Health

description.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Center for Global Health (CGH) Division of Global Health Protection (GHP) Emergency Response and Recovery Branch (ERRB) applies public health and epidemiologic science to reduce the health impact of disasters and emergencies, including complex humanitarian events and to strengthen the recovery of health systems in these settings.

title.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: Parasitic Diseases Prevention and Control

description.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Center for Global Health (CGH) Division of Parasitic Diseases and Malaria (DPDM) works to protect the health of people around the world from parasitic diseases, including malaria, through evidence-based public health action. DPDM works international partners to: prevent and control malaria, including co-implementing the U.S. Presidents Malaria Initiative (PMI), which is led by the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID); prevent, control, and eliminate neglected tropical diseases (NTDs); provide cross-cutting entomologic expertise and support; provide essential laboratory support to countries, and other partners; and conduct vital research and program evaluation.

title.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: Polio Eradication

description.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Center for Global Health (CGH) Global Immunization Division (GID) plays a critical role in eradicating polio by providing scientific leadership and guidance at the global, regional and country level to implement evidence-based strategies. Over the past 31 years, CDC, ministries of health, and Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI) partners work together across these areas to reach and vaccinate communities worldwide. CDC continues to provide technical assistance to endemic countries, outbreak countries, and other high-risk countries. CDC focuses on several key areas including data and analysis, laboratory capacity building, outbreak response and program development, routine immunization, and research and innovation.

title.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: Polio Eradication

description.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Center for Global Health (CGH) Global Immunization Division (GID) plays a critical role in eradicating polio by providing scientific leadership and guidance at the global, regional and country level to implement evidence-based strategies. Over the past 31 years, CDC, ministries of health, and Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI) partners work together across these areas to reach and vaccinate communities worldwide. CDC continues to provide technical assistance to endemic countries, outbreak countries, and other high-risk countries. CDC focuses on several key areas including data and analysis, laboratory capacity building, outbreak response and program development, routine immunization, and research and innovation.

title.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: Public Health Preparedness and Response

description.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Center for Preparedness and Response (CPR) staff work at CDC offices and in health departments to guide communities through public health crises. HHS/CDC/CPR also funds health departments to prepare and lead local responses to emergencies. Additionally, HHS/CDC/CPR fosters research and innovation in preparation for and response to public health emergencies.

title.narrative: CDC Investigations and Technical Assistance: Global Non-Communicable Disease Prevention and Promotion of Health

description.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Investigations and Technical Assistance assists national and local health authorities and other health related organizations in controlling communicable diseases, chronic diseases and disorders, and other preventable health conditions. Investigations and evaluation of all methods of controlling or preventing disease and disability are carried out by providing epidemic aid, surveillance, technical assistance, consultation, and program support; and by providing leadership and coordination of joint national, state, and local efforts.

title.narrative: CDC: Global Health Programs (Polio Eradication)

description.narrative: CDC has provided epidemiologic, laboratory, programmatic expertise, and funding support to help polio-endemic countries with polio eradication activities. The Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI) goal is to eradicate polio and certify the world as polio-free as soon as possible.

title.narrative: Protecting and Improving Health Globally:Building and Strengthening Public Health Impact, Systems,Capacity and Security

description.narrative: APHL-CDC Partnership to Strengthen Public Health Laboratories Internationally. U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) global health efforts are to assist Ministries of Health and other international partners to plan, manage effectively, and evaluate public health programs; achieve U.S. Government program and international organization goals to improve health, including disease eradication and elimination targets; expand CDC's global health programs that focus on the leading causes of worldwide mortality, morbidity and disability, including chronic disease and injuries; generate and apply new knowledge to achieve health goals; and, strengthen health systems and their impact.

description.narrative: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) Office of the Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response (ASPR): Grants. Technical Assistance and Provision for Foreign Hospitals and Health Organizations: Alerting and Surveillance for Infectious Disease Epidemics. To provide support for a quality of care improvement project based in a partner healthcare institution around the world, to provide continuing education and refresher training to physicians and other staff at hospitals and other Health Organizations around the world, and strengthen support and relations with Ministers of Public Health (MOPH).

title.narrative: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC): Complex Humanitarian Emergency and War-Related Injury Public Health Activities

description.narrative: To bring public health and epidemiologic principles to the aid of populations affected by complex humanitarian emergencies. Work will focus on the following main program areas: (1) Providing technical assistance including rapid health and nutrition assessments, public health surveillance, epidemic investigations, disease prevention and control, program evaluation and emergency preparedness; (2) Developing, implementing and disseminating findings from operational research projects aimed at developing more effective public health interventions; (3) Designing, implementing, and evaluating training activities to strengthen the capacity of CDC, other U.S. government agencies, international and private voluntary organizations, other governments, and public health students; (4) Developing and disseminating guidelines on public health issues and technical areas; and (5) Planning and maintaining partnerships with strategic international, bilateral, and non-governmental relief organizations.

title.narrative: Advancing National Public Health Institutes Globally

description.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Investigations and Technical Assistance assists national and local health authorities and other health related organizations in controlling communicable diseases, chronic diseases and disorders, and other preventable health conditions. Investigations and evaluation of all methods of controlling or preventing disease and disability are carried out by providing epidemic aid, surveillance, technical assistance, consultation, and program support; and by providing leadership and coordination of joint national, state, and local efforts.

title.narrative: Tuberculosis Demonstration, Research, Public and Professional Education: CRDF Global Support to Manage TB-Related Activities

description.narrative: To assist states, political subdivisions of States, and other public and nonprofit private entities in conducting research into prevention and control of tuberculosis (TB) nationally and internationally. To conduct demonstration projects, provide TB and latent TB infections (LTBI) communication, education, training, medical consultation activities to TB programs, private providers, and other partners for the prevention and control of TB.

title.narrative: Global AIDS: Technical Assistance Services to Countries Supported by PEPFAR and the GFATM

description.narrative: The U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) is the U.S. Government initiative to help save the lives of those suffering from HIV/AIDS around the world. This historic commitment is the largest by any nation to combat a single disease internationally, and PEPFAR investments also help alleviate suffering from other diseases across the global health spectrum. PEPFAR is the cornerstone and largest component of the U.S. President's Global Health Initiative. With a special focus on improving the health of women, newborns and children, the Global Health Initiative's goal is to save the greatest number of lives by increasing and building upon what works and, then, supporting countries as they work to improve the health of their own people.

reporting-org.narrative: Department of Health and Human Services

title.narrative: Complex Humanitarian Emergency and War-Related Injury Public Health Activities: Improving Response to and Programming in Humanitarian Emergencies

description.narrative: To bring public health and epidemiologic principles to the aid of populations affected by complex humanitarian emergencies. Work will focus on the following main program areas: (1) Providing technical assistance including rapid health and nutrition assessments, public health surveillance, epidemic investigations, disease prevention and control, program evaluation and emergency preparedness; (2) Developing, implementing and disseminating findings from operational research projects aimed at developing more effective public health interventions; (3) Designing, implementing, and evaluating training activities to strengthen the capacity of CDC, other U.S. government agencies, international and private voluntary organizations, other governments, and public health students; (4) Developing and disseminating guidelines on public health issues and technical areas; and (5) Planning and maintaining partnerships with strategic international, bilateral, and non-governmental relief organizations.

title.narrative: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC): Complex Humanitarian Emergency and War-Related Injury Public Health Activities

description.narrative: To bring public health and epidemiologic principles to the aid of populations affected by complex humanitarian emergencies. Work will focus on the following main program areas: (1) Providing technical assistance including rapid health and nutrition assessments, public health surveillance, epidemic investigations, disease prevention and control, program evaluation and emergency preparedness; (2) Developing, implementing and disseminating findings from operational research projects aimed at developing more effective public health interventions; (3) Designing, implementing, and evaluating training activities to strengthen the capacity of CDC, other U.S. government agencies, international and private voluntary organizations, other governments, and public health students; (4) Developing and disseminating guidelines on public health issues and technical areas; and (5) Planning and maintaining partnerships with strategic international, bilateral, and non-governmental relief organizations.

title.narrative: Global AIDS: Strengthening Public Health Capacity and Strategic Information Systems through Cooperation and Support Services from the Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS) under the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR)

description.narrative: The U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) is the U.S. Government initiative to help save the lives of those suffering from HIV/AIDS around the world. This historic commitment is the largest by any nation to combat a single disease internationally, and PEPFAR investments also help alleviate suffering from other diseases across the global health spectrum. PEPFAR is the cornerstone and largest component of the U.S. President's Global Health Initiative. With a special focus on improving the health of women, newborns and children, the Global Health Initiative's goal is to save the greatest number of lives by increasing and building upon what works and, then, supporting countries as they work to improve the health of their own people.

title.narrative: Protecting and Improving Health Globally:Building and Strengthening Public Health Impact, Systems,Capacity and Security

description.narrative: Global Emergency Response and Recovery Partner Engagement: Expanding Efforts and Strategies to Improve Rapid Response to Public Health Emergencies Globally. U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) global health efforts are to assist Ministries of Health and other international partners to plan, manage effectively, and evaluate public health programs; achieve U.S. Government program and international organization goals to improve health, including disease eradication and elimination targets; expand CDC's global health programs that focus on the leading causes of worldwide mortality, morbidity and disability, including chronic disease and injuries; generate and apply new knowledge to achieve health goals; and, strengthen health systems and their impact.

description.narrative: Global Emergency Response and Recovery Partner Engagement: Expanding Efforts and Strategies to Improve Rapid Response to Public Health Emergencies Globally. U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) global health efforts are to assist Ministries of Health and other international partners to plan, manage effectively, and evaluate public health programs; achieve U.S. Government program and international organization goals to improve health, including disease eradication and elimination targets; expand CDC's global health programs that focus on the leading causes of worldwide mortality, morbidity and disability, including chronic disease and injuries; generate and apply new knowledge to achieve health goals; and, strengthen health systems and their impact.

title.narrative: Global AIDS: Strengthening Public Health Laboratory Systems in Cameroon under PEPFAR

description.narrative: The U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) is the U.S. Government initiative to help save the lives of those suffering from HIV/AIDS around the world. This historic commitment is the largest by any nation to combat a single disease internationally, and PEPFAR investments also help alleviate suffering from other diseases across the global health spectrum. PEPFAR is the cornerstone and largest component of the U.S. President's Global Health Initiative. With a special focus on improving the health of women, newborns and children, the Global Health Initiative's goal is to save the greatest number of lives by increasing and building upon what works and, then, supporting countries as they work to improve the health of their own people.

title.narrative: Tuberculosis Demonstration, Research, Public and Professional Education: Accelerating the Decline of Tuberculosis (TB) in High Burden Countries and Settings

description.narrative: To assist states, political subdivisions of States, and other public and nonprofit private entities in conducting research into prevention and control of tuberculosis (TB) nationally and internationally. To conduct demonstration projects, provide TB and latent TB infections (LTBI) communication, education, training, medical consultation activities to TB programs, private providers, and other partners for the prevention and control of TB.

title.narrative: Global AIDS: Regional Strengthening of HIV-focused Population-based National Surveys and Size Estimations (RESPONSE) under PEPFAR

description.narrative: The U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) is the U.S. Government initiative to help save the lives of those suffering from HIV/AIDS around the world. This historic commitment is the largest by any nation to combat a single disease internationally, and PEPFAR investments also help alleviate suffering from other diseases across the global health spectrum. PEPFAR is the cornerstone and largest component of the U.S. President's Global Health Initiative. With a special focus on improving the health of women, newborns and children, the Global Health Initiative's goal is to save the greatest number of lives by increasing and building upon what works and, then, supporting countries as they work to improve the health of their own people.

title.narrative: CDC-RFA-GH21-2127.NU2G Provide Comprehensive Packages of HIV Prevention, Care, a

description.narrative: The U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) is the U.S. Government initiative to help save the lives of those suffering from HIV/AIDS around the world. This historic commitment is the largest by any nation to combat a single disease internationally, and PEPFAR investments also help alleviate suffering from other diseases across the global health spectrum. PEPFAR is the cornerstone and largest component of the U.S. President's Global Health Initiative. With a special focus on improving the health of women, newborns and children, the Global Health Initiative's goal is to save the greatest number of lives by increasing and building upon what works and, then, supporting countries as they work to improve the health of their own people.

title.narrative: Protecting and Improving Health Globally:Building and Strengthening Public Health Impact, Systems,Capacity and Security

description.narrative: Enhancing Global Health Security: Expanding Efforts and Strategies to Protect and Improve Public Health Globally. U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) global health efforts are to assist Ministries of Health and other international partners to plan, manage effectively, and evaluate public health programs; achieve U.S. Government program and international organization goals to improve health, including disease eradication and elimination targets; expand CDC's global health programs that focus on the leading causes of worldwide mortality, morbidity and disability, including chronic disease and injuries; generate and apply new knowledge to achieve health goals; and, strengthen health systems and their impact.

reporting-org.narrative: Department of Health and Human Services

title.narrative: Protecting and Improving Health Globally:Building and Strengthening Public Health Impact, Systems,Capacity and Security in the Eastern Mediterranean Region

description.narrative: Strengthening sustainable public health capacity in the Eastern Mediterranean Region for polio eradication and routine immunization activities. U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) global health efforts are to assist Ministries of Health and other international partners to plan, manage effectively, and evaluate public health programs; achieve U.S. Government program and international organization goals to improve health, including disease eradication and elimination targets; expand CDC's global health programs that focus on the leading causes of worldwide mortality, morbidity and disability, including chronic disease and injuries; generate and apply new knowledge to achieve health goals; and, strengthen health systems and their impact.

reporting-org.narrative: Department of Health and Human Services

title.narrative: Building Capacity of the Public Health System to Improve Population Health through National Nonprofit Organizations

description.narrative: This program will assist state, local and national health departments, and other components of the public health system by making available to them capacity building assistance (including technical consultation, skills building/training, information, and technology transfer assistance) that will result in: systems and organizational efficiencies; a capable and qualified workforce; state-of-the-art information technology systems and integrated and standardized community and population data; improved planning, implementation and evaluation of evidence-based public health policies, laws, programs and services; results driven local and national public and private partnerships; and increased availability and accessibility of public health resources, such as publications, educational materials, syndicated website material, training curricula, assessments and evaluation tools, and other products for improvement of public health agencies and other agencies in the public health system.

title.narrative: CDC Investigations and Technical Assistance: American Society for Microbiology (ASM)-CDC Post-doctoral Research Fellowship in Infectious Diseases and Public Health

description.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Investigations and Technical Assistance assists national and local health authorities and other health related organizations in controlling communicable diseases, chronic diseases and disorders, and other preventable health conditions. Investigations and evaluation of all methods of controlling or preventing disease and disability are carried out by providing epidemic aid, surveillance, technical assistance, consultation, and program support; and by providing leadership and coordination of joint national, state, and local efforts.

title.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases - International Health Regulations

description.narrative: Addressing emerging infectious diseases and international health regulations. U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases (NCEZID) works with partners around the world to prevent illness, disability, and death caused by a wide range of infectious diseases - from the rare but deadly, like anthrax and Ebola, to the more common, like foodborne disease and healthcare-associated infections.

title.narrative: Protecting and Improving Health Globally: Building and Strengthening Public Health Impact, Systems, Capacity and Security

description.narrative: CDC-FAO Collaboration on: CDC One Health Zoonotic Disease Prioritization Workshops and Production of Diagnostic Reagents for Ferret Antisera. The purpose of this program is to protect the public health and safety by enhancing the capacity of public health agencies to effectively detect, respond, prevent and control known and emerging (or re-emerging) infectious diseases. The purpose of this program is to protect the public health and safety by enhancing the capacity of public health agencies to effectively detect, respond, prevent and control known and emerging (or re-emerging) infectious diseases. This is accomplished by providing financial and technical resources to (1) strengthen epidemiologic capacity; (2) enhance laboratory capacity; (3) improve health information systems; and (4) enhance collaboration among epidemiology, laboratory, and information systems components of public health departments.

Investigations and evaluation of all methods of controlling or preventing disease and disability are carried out by providing epidemic aid, surveillance, technical assistance, consultation, and program support; and by providing leadership and coordination of joint national, state, and local efforts.

title.narrative: Protecting and Improving Health Globally:Building and Strengthening Public Health Impact, Systems,Capacity and Security

description.narrative: Expansion of seasonal influenza vaccination programs in low and middle income countries. U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) global health efforts are to assist Ministries of Health and other international partners to plan, manage effectively, and evaluate public health programs; achieve U.S. Government program and international organization goals to improve health, including disease eradication and elimination targets; expand CDC's global health programs that focus on the leading causes of worldwide mortality, morbidity and disability, including chronic disease and injuries; generate and apply new knowledge to achieve health goals; and, strengthen health systems and their impact.

title.narrative: Complex Humanitarian Emergency and War-Related Injury Public Health Activities

description.narrative: Evidence based Approaches to War Related Injuries and Humanitarian Public Health. To bring public health and epidemiologic principles to the aid of populations affected by complex humanitarian emergencies. Work will focus on the following main program areas: (1) Providing technical assistance including rapid health and nutrition assessments, public health surveillance, epidemic investigations, disease prevention and control, program evaluation and emergency preparedness; (2) Developing, implementing and disseminating findings from operational research projects aimed at developing more effective public health interventions; (3) Designing, implementing, and evaluating training activities to strengthen the capacity of CDC, other U.S. government agencies, international and private voluntary organizations, other governments, and public health students; (4) Developing and disseminating guidelines on public health issues and technical areas; and (5) Planning and maintaining partnerships with strategic international, bilateral, and non-governmental relief organizations.

title.narrative: Prevention of Disease, Disabiliy and Death through Immunization and Control of Respiratory and Related Diseases: Direct Sequencing of Antibodies of the Influenza Immune Response

description.narrative: The purpose of this program is to strengthen capacity to prevent disease, disability, and death through immunization and control of respiratory and related diseases. The specific objectives may include, but are not limited to: 1. Increase the population of children and adults who are free from respiratory infectious disease complications. 2. Strengthen local, state, and national capacity for the early detection, investigation, response and control of respiratory infections in order to accelerate early recognition of respiratory threats and to mitigate the impact of their spread. 3. Control the rise in antimicrobial resistant respiratory infections in the community. 4. Strengthen prevention and control of respiratory infections in institutional settings, such as health care facilities and workplaces. 5. Reduce mortality from pneumonia and other severe respiratory infections. 6. Strengthen capacity for early detection, investigation, response, and control of respiratory infectious threats.

title.narrative: Prevention of Disease, Disability and Death by Infectious Diseases: Synthetic Biology for Field Detection of Zika in the United States and Abroad

description.narrative: The purpose of this program is to prevent disease, disability and death by infectious diseases. The specific objectives may include, but are not limited to: strengthening public health fundamentals; increasing capacity to prevent disease, disability and death; infectious disease surveillance; laboratory detection; epidemiologic investigation and public health response; expansion of public health and clinical laboratories in disease control and prevention; workforce development and training to sustain and strengthen public health practice; and increase community and individual engagement in disease prevention efforts; strengthen global capacity to detect and respond to outbreaks with the potential to cross borders.

title.narrative: Complex Humanitarian Emergency and War-Related Injury Public Health Activities

description.narrative: Integrated Protocol for Treatment of Moderate Accute Malnutrition (MAM) and Severe Accute Malnutrition (SAM) in Humanitarian Emergencies. To bring public health and epidemiologic principles to the aid of populations affected by complex humanitarian emergencies. Work will focus on the following main program areas: (1) Providing technical assistance including rapid health and nutrition assessments, public health surveillance, epidemic investigations, disease prevention and control, program evaluation and emergency preparedness; (2) Developing, implementing and disseminating findings from operational research projects aimed at developing more effective public health interventions; (3) Designing, implementing, and evaluating training activities to strengthen the capacity of CDC, other U.S. government agencies, international and private voluntary organizations, other governments, and public health students; (4) Developing and disseminating guidelines on public health issues and technical areas; and (5) Planning and maintaining partnerships with strategic international, bilateral, and non-governmental relief organizations.

title.narrative: Tuberculosis Demonstration, Research, Public and Professional Education: Addressing Global TB Prevention and Control in all Populations

description.narrative: To assist states, political subdivisions of States, and other public and nonprofit private entities in conducting research into prevention and control of tuberculosis (TB) nationally and internationally. To conduct demonstration projects, provide TB and latent TB infections (LTBI) communication, education, training, medical consultation activities to TB programs, private providers, and other partners for the prevention and control of TB.

title.narrative: Health Systems Strengthening and HIV/AIDS Prevention, Care and Treatment under the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief: Quality Improvement Solutions for Sustained Epidemic Control Project (QISSEC)

description.narrative: The purpose of the Quality Improvement Solutions for Sustained Epidemic Control Project (QISSEC) is to facilitate improvements in quality across the HIV care continuum at the site level (defined as the location where persons diagnosed with HIV receive care and treatment) and within the community. The project aims to facilitate solutions for long-term change management approaches and sustainability of QA and QI activity. Activities are appropriately monitored, data and performance driven, and approaches and strategies implemented explore and introduce new and innovative solutions to achieve sustainable impact.

title.narrative: CDC Investigations and Technical Assistance: CDC's Collaboration with Academia to Strengthen Public Health Workforce Capacity - Polio Eradication

description.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Investigations and Technical Assistance assists national and local health authorities and other health related organizations in controlling communicable diseases, chronic diseases and disorders, and other preventable health conditions. Investigations and evaluation of all methods of controlling or preventing disease and disability are carried out by providing epidemic aid, surveillance, technical assistance, consultation, and program support; and by providing leadership and coordination of joint national, state, and local efforts.

description.narrative: The funded Prevention Research Centers aims are to: 1. Establish, maintain, and operate multi-disciplinary academic-based centers that conduct high-quality applied health promotion and disease prevention research; 2. Improve public health practice through applied prevention research; 3. Apply the knowledge and expertise of academic health centers to address practical public health problems; 4. Design, implement, evaluate, and disseminate cost-effective methods and strategies for health promotion and disease prevention at the tribal, territorial, state, or local level; 5. Shorten the time lag between the development of new and proven effective disease prevention and health promotion strategies and interventions and their widespread application; and 6. Involve health departments and other community partners in the development, implementation, evaluation, and dissemination of one applied public health prevention research project.

title.narrative: CDC Investigations and Technical Assistance: Cooperative Agreement with the World Health Organization to Address Emerging Infectious Diseases and International Health Regulations

description.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Investigations and Technical Assistance assists national and local health authorities and other health related organizations in controlling communicable diseases, chronic diseases and disorders, and other preventable health conditions. Investigations and evaluation of all methods of controlling or preventing disease and disability are carried out by providing epidemic aid, surveillance, technical assistance, consultation, and program support; and by providing leadership and coordination of joint national, state, and local efforts.

reporting-org.narrative: Department of Health and Human Services

title.narrative: Complex Humanitarian Emergency and War-Related Injury Public Health Activities

description.narrative: Evidence based Approaches to War Related Injuries and Humanitarian Public Health. To bring public health and epidemiologic principles to the aid of populations affected by complex humanitarian emergencies. Work will focus on the following main program areas: (1) Providing technical assistance including rapid health and nutrition assessments, public health surveillance, epidemic investigations, disease prevention and control, program evaluation and emergency preparedness; (2) Developing, implementing and disseminating findings from operational research projects aimed at developing more effective public health interventions; (3) Designing, implementing, and evaluating training activities to strengthen the capacity of CDC, other U.S. government agencies, international and private voluntary organizations, other governments, and public health students; (4) Developing and disseminating guidelines on public health issues and technical areas; and (5) Planning and maintaining partnerships with strategic international, bilateral, and non-governmental relief organizations.

title.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: Global Health Activities

description.narrative: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Center for Global Health (CGH) leads the execution of CDC's global health approach, working in partnership to assist Ministries of Health to plan, manage effectively, and evaluate health programs; achieve U.S. Government program and international organization goals to improve health, including disease eradication and elimination targets; expand CDC's global health programs that focus on the leading causes of mortality, morbidity and disability, especially chronic disease and injuries; generate and apply new knowledge to achieve health goals; and strengthen health systems and their impact.
